articles.description:
JOHANNESBURG, Nov 08 (IPS) - The news in many parts of the world is that tuberculosis (TB) is reclaiming the title of the world’s most deadly infection, even as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to kill an estimated 1,450 people daily around the world. But this is not news to African countries, which are home to one third of the people globally who die from TB, even though they have less than one fifth of the world’s population.

Read the full story, “Progress on Tuberculosis Can Be Achieved in Africa”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Progress on Tuberculosis Can Be Achieved in Africa

articles.description:

articles.description:
ROME, Nov 07 (IPS) - Arms are raised, stretched out towards the sky, holding white cards with the word "peace" written in different languages. A girl, a refugee from Syria, reads the Rome’s "Appeal for peace": "With firm conviction, we say: no more war! Let's stop all conflicts […] Let dialogue be resumed to nullify the threat of nuclear weapons.” Pope Francis singed it in front of the people gathered at the Colosseum, holding the word “peace” in their hands, as representatives of the world’s religions did as well. Shortly before, members of those different religions gathered for prayer to invoke peace in their different traditions—a prayer that is “a cry” inside the ancient amphitheater.

Read the full story, “Lessons from Rome. Weaving Peace Is a Polyphonic Dialogue”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Lessons from Rome. Weaving Peace Is a Polyphonic Dialogue

articles.description:
With climate-related disasters displacing more people than conflict, UN Secretary-General António Guterres on Monday unveiled the details of his plan to ensure everyone on the planet is protected by early warning systems within the next five years. 

Read the full story, “COP27: $3.1 billion plan to achieve early warning systems for all by 2027”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: COP27: $3.1 billion plan to achieve early warning systems for all by 2027

articles.description:
Although the global cost-of-living crisis will be an obstacle to eradicating poverty by 2030, countries can still make significant progress towards this Sustainable Development Goal (SDG), UN-appointed human rights expert Olivier de Schutter has said. 

Read the full story, “Like racism and sexism, ‘povertyism’ should be illegal, UN rights expert says”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Like racism and sexism, ‘povertyism’ should be illegal, UN rights expert says

articles.description:
The top UN disarmament official told the Security Council on Monday that “gaps, inconsistencies and discrepancies” identified in Syria’s declaration over its use of chemical weapons, in accordance with the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC). “cannot be considered accurate and complete”.  

Read the full story, “‘Gaps, inconsistencies and discrepancies’ continue over Syria’s chemical weapons stance, Security Council hears”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: ‘Gaps, inconsistencies and discrepancies’ continue over Syria’s chemical weapons stance, Security Council hears

articles.description:
Global action to fight illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing has intensified, the Food and Agriculture Organization said on Monday, noting that 100 States have now signed on to an international agreement battling the scourge.

Read the full story, “New milestone in battle against illegal, unregulated fishing”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: New milestone in battle against illegal, unregulated fishing

articles.description: Tuesday's midterm elections come at a time of economic vulnerability for the United States. Recession predictions have largely turned to "when" not "if" and inflation remains stubbornly elevated. Americans are feeling the pain of rising interest rates and are facing a winter filled with geopolitical tension.
articles.title: What midterm elections could mean for the US economy

articles.description: A magnitude 5.6 earthquake hit western Nepal on Wednesday morning local time, killing at least five people, according to local officials.
articles.title: Western Nepal hit by magnitude 5.6 earthquake killing at least five people, say officials

articles.description: The US and Russia have agreed to hold talks on the single existing nuclear treaty between the two countries in the near future, State Department spokesperson Ned Price said on Tuesday.
articles.title: US and Russia agree to hold talks on nuclear treaty for first time since Ukraine war began

articles.description: A US citizen was murdered in Baghdad on Monday, according to Iraqi Prime Minister Muhammad Shia al-Sudani.
articles.title: US citizen murdered in Baghdad attack

articles.description: Samuel Roe, regional sales manager for Terlato Wines, had business associates visiting a few weeks ago and called a friend at one of the most expensive rooftop eateries in New York to ask if his group could get a table.
articles.title: Corporate entertaining has come roaring back

articles.description: Russian troops have denounced an "incomprehensible battle" in Donetsk after apparently sustaining heavy losses during a week of intense fighting in the key eastern region of Ukraine.
articles.title: Russian troops slam generals over 'incomprehensible battle'

articles.description: A pair of dogs gifted by North Korea are the center of a political dispute in South Korea after the country's former President said he was giving them up over an apparent lack of legal and financial support from his successor to care for the animals.
articles.title: North Korean 'peace' dogs cause political spat in South Korea

articles.description: Taiwan's latest entrant to Wall Street has had a rough ride since it went public a week ago.
articles.title: Taiwan's virtual beauty brand struggles on Wall Street debut

articles.description: Shares of used car marketplace Carvana continued to plummet Monday, falling over 50% over the past two trading days, following a volatile downward trend that began after the company shared third-quarter results Thursday.
articles.title: Carvana stock plummets as used car prices fall

articles.description: Pakistan's former Prime Minister Imran Khan has told CNN he had information from within intelligence agencies that the shooting which injured him last week would take place.
articles.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Khan claims he had prior intel on rally shooting

articles.description: A branch of Ukraine's Orthodox church has announced that it will allow its churches to celebrate Christmas on December 25, rather than January 7, as is traditional in Orthodox congregations.
articles.title: Orthodox Church of Ukraine to allow Christmas on December 25 as rift with Moscow deepens

articles.description: While investors, business leaders and some economic models continue to warn a recession is imminent, Wall Street's most powerful investment bank remains cautiously optimistic.
articles.title: A recession in the US is not a slam dunk, Goldman Sachs says

articles.description: Celebrities alighted in Miami Beach on Friday evening as French fashion house Chanel hosted a stateside iteration of its Cruise 2022-2023 show.
articles.title: Inside Chanel's star-studded show in Miami

articles.description: Ryanair carried a record number of passengers over the summer and says its budget friendly airfares will attract even more customers as Europe falls into a recession.
articles.title: Millions of passengers are switching to this budget friendly airline

articles.description: China has reiterated its unswerving commitment to its longstanding zero-Covid policy, despite mounting public frustration the stringent measures are costing the very lives they're intended to protect.
articles.title: What exit? China doubles down on zero-Covid pledge despite public frustration

articles.description: The deteriorating health of jailed Egyptian-British activist, Alaa Abd El-Fattah will dominate the upcoming COP27 summit if Egyptian authorities fail to intervene, Amnesty International has warned.
articles.title: Hunger strike of jailed Egyptian-British activist may dominate the COP27 summit, Amnesty chief warns

articles.description: "Someone's crime was that her hair was flowing in the wind. Someone's crime was that he or she was brave and were outspoken."
articles.title: Family fears for life of rapper they say was violently arrested after encouraging Iranians to protest

articles.description: A Tanzanian commercial flight operated by Precision Air crash-landed in bad weather in Lake Victoria on Sunday, killing 19 people.
articles.title: 19 dead after commercial aircraft crashes into Lake Victoria in Tanzania

articles.description: The UN agencies in Colombo in a joint statement said they had raised $79 million to feed those in need, but the increasing number of poor people meant they needed an additional $70 million.
articles.title: UN warns of worsening food crisis in Sri Lanka

articles.description: Storm Nicole, packing maximum sustained winds of 50 miles per hour (80 km per hour), was located about 385 miles (615 km) northwest of the Bahamas as it moved west toward Florida, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) said in an advisory on Tuesday morning. With the storm expected to strengthen throughout the day as it traveled at 8 mph toward Florida, some 18 million people along the state's Atlantic coast were under NHC issued watches and warnings.
articles.title: Florida's Atlantic coast prepares for Storm Nicole

articles.description: The numbers for a record-breaking $2.04 billion Powerball jackpot have been drawn following a delay and players were awaiting the announcement of a possible winner.
articles.title: Winning numbers for $2.04B Powerball drawn after delay

articles.description: With the narrowly held House and an evenly split Senate, Democrats could easily see their fragile grasp on power slip as they face a new generation of Republican candidates. Among them are political newcomers to public office, including skeptics, deniers of the 2020 election and some extremists inspired by Donald Trump.
articles.title: Republicans look to win back power in Congress, stop Biden

articles.description: Some of China’s most persistent virus hotspots have been locked down for weeks, and in some cases months, showing the limitations of the country’s contentious Covid Zero policy. Xinjiang reported the fourth-highest number of new cases nationally for Monday, according to data compiled by Bloomberg, despite some cities in the region in China’s northwest locked down for 90 days.
articles.title: China’s lockdowns fail to contain Covid as people’s anger grows

articles.description: Days after Twitter Inc fired half its staff and new owner Elon Musk tweeted a recommendation to vote for Republican candidates, election experts are anxiously bracing for a surge in online misinformation as Americans head to the polls on Tuesday.
articles.title: Elon Musk's Twitter girds for surge in US midterm election misinformation

articles.description: Ukraine's president has hinted at the possibility of peace talks with Russia, a shift from his earlier refusal to negotiate with President Vladimir Putin that came on the eve of crucial elections in the United States. Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged the international community late Monday to “force Russia into real peace talks" and listed his usual conditions for dialogue: the return of all of Ukraine's occupied lands, compensation for damage caused by the war and the prosecution of war crimes.
articles.title: Talks with Russia possible on Ukraine's terms, says Zelenskyy

articles.description: Middle East News: PARIS: Iran has deployed mounted police in a bid to contain more than seven weeks of protests sparked by the death in custody of Mahsa Amini, accordin.
articles.title: Iran deploys mounted police to quell Mahsa Amini protests

articles.description: New coronavirus cases surged in Guangzhou and other Chinese cities, official data showed on Tuesday, with the global manufacturing hub becoming China's latest Covid-19 epicentre and testing the city's ability to avoid a Shanghai-style lockdown. Guangzhou reported 2,377 new local cases for November 7, up from 1,971 the previous day. It was a dramatic jump from double-digit increases two weeks ago.
articles.title: China's Covid epicentre shifts to Guangzhou, more lockdowns loom

articles.description: US News: BOWIE (US): President Joe Biden made a final appeal on the eve of Tuesday's midterms for Democrats to protect democracy by defeating Donald Trump's Re.
articles.title: Biden urges Americans to 'defend' democracy on election eve

articles.title: Imran Khan's assassination bid: Police finally register FIR

articles.title: Americans convicted in Japan on Ghosn's escape return home

articles.description: Biden's Democrats are facing a gargantuan struggle to hang on to Congress, after a race the president has cast as a "defining" moment for US democracy -- while Trump's Republicans campaigned hard on kitchen-table issues like inflation and crime. Trump grabbed the election eve spotlight to flag "a big announcement" a week from now on November 15, while Biden made a final appeal to Democrats to turn out en masse at the polls.
articles.title: US votes with Biden agenda at stake - and Trump in the wings

articles.description: China News: BEIJING: A scaled-down version of China's biggest air show opened on Tuesday, with some delegates unable to attend because of the country's zero-Covid.
articles.title: China's biggest air show opens under cloud of zero-Covid policy

articles.description: India News: NEW DELHI: US house speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Monday the recent attack on her husband by a hammer-wielding intruder in their home was especially pa.
articles.title: Pelosi says attack on her husband will affect decision whether to retire

articles.description: South Asia News: COLOMBO: Sri Lanka's navy said Monday that about 300 suspected migrants have been rescued by Singapore authorities after their boat started sinking.
articles.title: Singapore rescues 300 suspected migrants from sinking boat

articles.description: Donald Trump said Monday he would be making a "very big announcement" next week. "Not to detract from tomorrow's very important, even critical election ... I'm going to be making a very big announcement on Tuesday, November 15 at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida," Trump told a cheering crowd in Ohio on the eve of US polls which will determine control of Congress.
articles.title: Trump: I am going to make 'very big announcement' on Nov 15

articles.description: Xinjiang reported the fourth-highest number of new cases nationally for Monday, according to data compiled by Bloomberg, despite some cities in the region in China's northwest locked down for 90 days. Inner Mongolia, which was sealed off in early October, saw cases jump to almost 1,800 from 1,033 a day earlier, while Henan province's infections more than doubled in a day to 747.
articles.title: China's long lockdowns struggle to contain growing outbreaks

articles.description: Elon Musk, Twitter's new owner, urged Americans to elect a Republican Congress in US midterms on Tuesday to counterbalance President Joe Biden's Democrats, the first time a major social media CEO explicitly took a side. "Shared power curbs the worst excesses of both parties, therefore I recommend voting for a Republican Congress, given that the Presidency is Democratic," Musk said in a tweet.
articles.title: Musk backs Republicans on eve of US midterms

articles.description: Ahead of foreign minister S Jaishankar’s talks with his counterpart Sergey Lavrov on Ukraine and other regional and global issues, Russia emphasised both countries shared similar positions on “most pressing issues” and also in their adherence to international law and the UN Charter, which the West has accused Russia of violating by invading and annexing Ukrainian territory.
articles.title: India and Russia seek polycentric world: Moscow ahead of EAM trip

articles.description: Middle East News: SHARM EL SHEIKH: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said on Monday the kingdom would contribute $2.
articles.title: Saudi Arabia commits $2.5 billion to Middle East green initiative: Salman

articles.description: UK News: LONDON: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said on Monday he was optimistic about working with France and other European nations to tackle illegal mig.
articles.title: UK PM Sunak says he has 'renewed confidence' about tackling illegal migration

articles.description: Europe News: Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Monday that 50,000 Russian soldiers called up as part of his mobilisation drive were now serving with combat .
articles.title: Putin says 50,000 mobilised Russian soldiers serving with combat units

articles.description: Ukraine announced Monday it had received more air defence systems from Western military allies, as officials in Kyiv said the situation with supplies was "tense" after protracted Russian attacks on energy facilities. Attacks by Moscow's forces, including with Iranian-made drones over the past month, have destroyed around 40 percent of Ukraine's power stations and the government has urged Ukrainians to maximise electricity savings.
articles.title: Ukraine hails new air defences, warns power situation 'tense'

articles.description: Ukraine accused Russia on Monday of looting empty homes in the southern city of Kherson and occupying them with troops in civilian clothes to prepare for street fighting in what both sides predict will be one of the war's most important battles. In recent days Russia has ordered civilians out of Kherson in anticipation of a Ukrainian assault to recapture the city, the only regional capital Moscow has seized since its invasion in February.
articles.title: Ukraine says Russian troops loot, occupy Kherson homes as battle looms

articles.description: Russia's defence ministry took the unusual step on Monday of denying reports by Russian military bloggers that a naval infantry unit had lost hundreds of men in a fruitless offensive in eastern Ukraine, the state-owned RIA news agency said. It said the ministry had rejected the bloggers' assertions that the 155th marine brigade of the Pacific Fleet had suffered "high, pointless losses in people and equipment".
articles.title: Russia issues rare denial of 'pointless losses' by brigade in Ukraine

articles.description: Europe News: KYIV: Russian-appointed authorities say they are working to partially restore power in the occupied Ukrainian city of Kherson following what they have.
articles.title: Russian authorities: Power back on in occupied Kherson

articles.description: Pakistan News: LAHORE: Pakistan's former foreign minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has said that he will lead the march to Islamabad until Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI).
articles.title: Pak's former foreign minister Qureshi to lead march until Imran recovers

articles.description: Pakistan News: ISLAMABAD: Imran Khan has outclassed Bollywood stars Shah Rukh Khan and Salman Khan in acting skills, veteran Pakistani politician Maulana Fazlur Rehm.
articles.title: 'Imran Khan outshines Shah Rukh, Salman in acting skills'

articles.description: The Nov. 1 ballot saw Religious Zionism, a hard-line settler party, soar to third place in parliament, positioning it as a potential powerful partner in Benjamin Netanyahu's likely coalition. Negotiations started on Sunday and could take weeks.
articles.title: Israeli settlers have high hopes after Netanyahu election win

articles.description: Rest of World News: MANILA: The Philippines' police accused on Monday the country's prisons chief of ordering the killing of a prominent radio journalist, whose death spa.
articles.title: Philippine prisons chief ordered murder of journalist: Police

articles.description: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned on Sunday against more potential Russian attacks on energy infrastructure, while the mayor of Kyiv urged residents to consider preparing to leave temporarily if the capital lost water and power supplies. In regular nightly remarks, Zelenskyy said Russia was "concentrating forces and means for a possible repetition of mass attacks on our infrastructure."
articles.title: Ukraine warns of more attacks on infrastructure

articles.description: With all 435 seats in the House of Representatives up for grabs alongside a third of the 100-member Senate, Democrats were putting a brave face on their prospects- but the latest polls have put them on the defensive. US midterm elections are typically seen as a referendum on the president in power, whose party tends to lose seats in Congress, particularly if- as with Biden- his approval rating is under 50%.
articles.title: Biden says democracy at stake as Republicans eye 'red wave'

articles.description: Beijing has shut schools in its most populous district, ordering students to study from home as an outbreak in the capital persists. Multiple schools in the Chaoyang district, home to corporate headquarters and embassies, halted in-person schooling from Monday, according to social media posts, although there's been no official government statement.
articles.title: China covid cases jump to 6-month high as outbreaks flare

articles.description: In September, commander Gryshchenko helped push Moscow's forces back across the border near Kharkiv. The retreat marked one of the high points of the Ukrainian counteroffensive in the northeast. Now, Kyiv's troops in the village of Starytsya stand so close to Russia that some phones mistakenly get texts to say they've arrived in the country. Gryshchenko's troops are keeping watch.
articles.title: Ukrainian soldiers keep watch at recaptured border

articles.description: An award-winning Hong Kong journalist lost her appeal Monday against her conviction over making false statements in obtaining information for her investigation of a violent attack during the widespread protests in 2019. Hong Kong fell more than 60 places to 148th place in Reporters Without Borders' latest World Press Freedom Index released in May.
articles.title: Hong Kong court upholds veteran journalist's conviction

articles.description: North Korea's military said Monday its recent barrage of missile tests were practices to attack its rivals' air bases and warplanes and paralyse their operation command systems, showing Pyongyang's resolve to counter provocative US-South Korean military drills “more thoroughly and mercilessly.”
articles.title: North Korea: Missile tests were practice to attack South, US

articles.description: The request by American officials was not aimed at pushing Ukraine to the negotiating table, but a calculated attempt to ensure Kyiv maintains the support of other nations facing constituencies wary of fueling a war for many years to come.

articles.description:
Oct. 28-Nov. 3, 2022

This photo gallery highlights some of the most compelling images made or published by Associated Press photographers in Latin America and the Caribbean. It was curated by AP photo editor Anita Baca in Mexico City.

Follow AP visual journalism:

Instagram:         https://www.instagram.com/apnews     

AP Images on Twitter:         http://twitter.com/AP—Images     

AP Images blog:         http://apimagesblog.com

articles.description:
World leaders gather at COP27 in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, on November 7, to hash out climate action at a time of high inflation and soaring energy prices. | Sean Gallup/Getty Images
    

  
What can COP27 accomplish as inflation and energy prices soar?
 President Joe Biden and other world leaders are gathering this week in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, for negotiations on mitigating climate change. The two-week meeting, known as COP27, follows yet another year of devastating floods, storms, heat waves, and droughts around the world, worsened by rising average temperatures. 
Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere this year reached 421 parts per million, the highest in human history, and the planet just experienced one of its hottest summers on record.  
But climate change isn’t the only issue on…

articles.description: Alerts are "screaming" in more than 10 Ukrainian regions, it emerged tonight, with multiple reports of the warnings sounding.
articles.title: Air raid sirens sound across most of Ukraine as Russian missiles 'inbound from sea'

articles.description: The Twitter CEO was heavily criticised for posting a meme featuring a Nazi soldier after poking fun at the world's technological advancements.
articles.title: Elon Musk criticised for posting 'Wermacht imagery' in new Twitter post

articles.description: People who are gay and engage in sex while in Qatar for the World Cup could face up to three years in prison, heavy fines or even the death penalty under Sharia Law. Qatari ambassador Khalid Salman said he expected anyone to accept the country's rules.
articles.title: Qatari World Cup ambassador brands homosexuality 'damage in the mind'

articles.description: Responding to "creepy" comments posted online, a social media user asked: "What makes you think this is an appropriate place to give your opinion on her appearance?"
articles.title: Police detective gets trolled on social media by sexist comments after picture released

articles.description: A Russian military cleric and proponent of the invasion of Ukraine was killed by an exploding HIMARS rocket while on the front line.
articles.title: Putin’s priest who demanded Russian women have more sons after war deaths blown up

articles.description: A 22-year-old Australian motorist has allegedly been caught driving at 174mph in a Volkswagen Golf.
articles.title: Boy racer slammed and has licence torn apart after clocking 174 mph

articles.description: Throughout the war, Russian fighters have frequently been able to launch radar-homing air-to-air missiles at Ukrainian fighters from over 100km away.
articles.title: Ukraine LIVE: West 'urgently' asked to step in - Putin turbocharges air campaign of terror

articles.description: Vladimir Putin has been dealt yet another humiliating blow as the increasingly low morale of Russian troops sees them accuse the Kremlin of causing a "massacre" due to military "incompetence".
articles.title: Putin’s regime accused by marines of calling troops ‘cannon fodder’ amid ‘massacre’

articles.description: Health experts have warned a Covid "variant soup" is behind recent outbreaks, as the World Health Organisation identifies hundreds of new "sub variants" emerging from Omicron.
articles.title: Health experts warn Covid outbreaks spurred by 'variant soup' as WHO discovers 300 strains

articles.description: Ukrainian President Volodymr Zelensky warned of ‘mass attacks' on the country's power grid as Kyiv's mayor Vitali Klitschko said widespread evacuations in the capital may soon be needed.
articles.title: Warning of mass evacuations in Ukraine after Russian 'mass attacks' on power grid

articles.description: Ukraine has been crippled with blackouts after Russia launched nationwide attacks on critical energy and water infrastructure.
articles.title: Ukraine army strikes Russian tank in fiery explosion as country plunges into blackout

articles.description: Vladimir Putin's military ploy to threaten a second push on Ukraine from Belarus has been debunked by a Belarussian opposition insider.
articles.title: Putin shamed as plans for second Ukraine front reduced to Belarus training camp mind game

articles.description: Mona Seif, the sister of the jailed British-Egyptian activist Alaa Abd El-Fattah, has a message for British leaders at COP27: "Don't come home without my brother."
articles.title: Sister of jailed Brit on brink of death in Egypt warns PM: 'Don't come home without him'

articles.description: Russian forces look to be withdrawing from the strategic city of Kherson, destroying their military supplies in the process, in preparation for a counterattack after Ukraine has recaptured the region.
articles.title: Russian soldier admits Moscow ‘blowing up ammunition’ in Kherson in leaked call

articles.description: Vladimir Putin's opposers believe the Russian President could only be ousted with a revolution at the cost of initiating a civil war in Russia.
articles.title: Putin's enemies gather in Poland and hatch plot to 'eliminate' Russian despot in civil war

articles.description: The Kremlin leader's comments have sparked fears of a potential nuclear strike in the east of Ukraine.
articles.title: Ukraine LIVE: Putin invokes WW2 in nuclear threat as ‘all options are on table’

articles.description: British intelligence suggests that another of Russia's military chiefs tasked with the war in Ukraine has been replaced following humiliating retreats.
articles.title: Putin’s top general dubbed ‘Hero of Russia’ mysteriously removed from command

articles.description: Rishi Sunak will on Monday call on nations around the world to turn the struggle against climate change into a global mission for clean growth and new jobs.
articles.title: Sunak urges nations to use green fight to spark mass job creation

articles.description: The US is privately calling on Ukraine to consider negotiation with Moscow or face weakening support from other nations, according to America's media.
articles.title: The US is 'secretly urging Ukraine to talk peace' with Russia

articles.description: A badly-timed Russian offensive in Donetsk has backfired badly on the troops and led to a "slaughter" among the forces, as one letter begging for help revealed.
articles.title: Russian troops plead for help after Putin's latest offensive turns into 'death trap'

articles.description: Joe Biden is widely seen as having sent a clear signal to Putin with the US's confirmation that it is sending upgraded nuclear weapons to Europe before the end of the year.
articles.title: Putin may ‘test West’ after Biden sent enhanced nuclear weapons to Europe, warns Ellwood

articles.description: Russia's economy is worth just £1.5trillion while NATO has a combined worth of £35trillion.
articles.title: 'Putin doesn't stand a chance' as Russia's economy too small to take on NATO

sources.title: France 24 - International breaking news, top stories and headlines

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Tropical Storm Nicole gained strength on Tuesday as it churned toward the Bahamas on track for Florida's Atlantic coast, where a hurricane warning was posted for nearly 250 miles of shoreline with millions of residents warned to hunker down and prepare.
articles.title: Hurricane warning issued as tropical storm Nicole moves toward Florida

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday told France's biggest polluters they should cut their greenhouse gas emissions by half over the next decade and said there would be more public money available to help decarbonisethe economy if they acted quickly.
articles.title: Macron tells France's heavy polluters to cut emissions, promises aid

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The European Union's executive told its 27 member countries at a seminar on Monday that it was not possible to create a gas price cap that would not affect long-term contracts or supply security, two diplomatic sources told Reuters.
articles.title: EU Commission says gas price cap 'impossible'

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Militias fighting the military junta in Myanmar have turned to making their own DIY weapons, including rockets and mortars, as they take on a much more heavily armed adversary. But constructing the weapons is dangerous work, with accidents, particularly during testing, claiming the lives of militia members.
articles.title: Myanmar: The DIY weapons factories arming anti-junta fighters

articles.author: Sébastian SEIBT
articles.description: Egyptian authorities have unveiled a COP27 application to "help" participants at the climate change summit in Sharm El Skeikh, which ends on November 18. But NGOs and cybersecurity experts warn that President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi’s regime can very easily and effectively use the app to surveil attendees, including top diplomats and Egyptian activists.
articles.title: COP27 app gives Egypt’s Sisi access to every move attendees make

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Sweden's parliament said Tuesday it would vote next week on a constitutional amendment that would make it possible to beef up anti-terror laws, a key demand from Turkey to approve Stockholm's NATO membership bid.
articles.title: Swedish MPs to vote next week on beefing up anti-terror laws after Turkish request

articles.description: If you watched some of the videos on YouTube featuring young Uighur influencers, then you would have no idea that a growing number of human rights organisations and the United Nations have documented China’s severe repression of this Muslim ethnic minority. In a study published mid-October, an Australian research centre has dissected more than 1,700 videos to show how they are in fact part of the complex Chinese propaganda network under President Xi Jinping.
articles.title: The Uighur ‘influencers’ working for Beijing’s propaganda machine

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: US voters head to the polls on Tuesday for crucial midterm elections that threaten Democrats’ razor-thin majorities in the House of Representatives and Senate. President Joe Biden and Democratic candidates across the country have warned that American democracy is at stake and sought to highlight the rollback of abortion rights, while Republicans have blamed Democrats for high inflation and crime. Follow FRANCE 24's live blog throughout election day for all the latest developments.
articles.title: Live: Control of Congress at stake as most polls close in US midterm elections

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: A Nigerian social media influencer who called himself Ray Hushpuppi and flaunted a lavish lifestyle fueled by his efforts to launder millions of stolen dollars was sentenced Monday in Los Angeles to more than 11 years in federal prison.
articles.title: Nigerian influencer ‘Hushpuppi’ sentenced to 11 years in US prison for money laundering

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Ukraine denied on Tuesday that it was under Western pressure to negotiate with Russia, doubling down on its insistence that talks could take place only if Russia relinquishes all occupied territory. The remarks came days after a high profile Washington Post report that the United States had encouraged Kyiv to signal willingness for talks. It also coincided with US mid-term elections that could test Western support for Ukraine. All times are Paris time (GMT+1).
articles.title: Live: Ukraine denies Western pressure to soften stance on talks with Russia

articles.author: Stéphanie TROUILLARD
articles.description: On November 8, 1942, the Western Allies launched Operation Torch, landing in Vichy-controlled Morocco and Algeria to open up a second front in World War II. Torch was a paradoxical operation: The Allies won in just over a week, but losses were relatively high as the operation provided harsh lessons to be learned ahead of the D-Day landings 18 months later.
articles.title: Allies’ successful first invasion but a ‘botched’ job: Operation Torch, 80 years on

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: France's Caroline Garcia put on a serving masterclass to claim the biggest title of her career on Monday by defeating Aryna Sabalenka 7-6(4) 6-4 to win the WTA Finals in Fort Worth, Texas.
articles.title: Garcia wins WTA championship after straight-sets victory against Sabalenka

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: In a stark closing argument ahead of the U.S. midterm elections, President Joe Biden on Monday warned that a Republican victory could weaken the country's democratic institutions, while former President Donald Trump hinted he could announce another White House bid as soon as next week.
articles.title: US midterms: Biden warns of attacks on democracy, Trump hints he'll announce bid next week

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Armenia and Azerbaijan held peace talks on Monday, mediated by the United States, just hours after a fresh shootout along their troubled border in a conflict which has left hundreds dead in recent months.
articles.title: Armenia, Azerbaijan hold US sponsored talks hours after new border shootout

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Oath Keepers founder Stewart Rhodes denied Monday in his sedition trial that his organization planned the January 6, 2021 assault on the US Capitol, calling those who entered the building "stupid."
articles.title: Oath Keepers militia founder denies planning Jan. 6 attach on US Capitol

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Callac, a small, normally tranquil town rural Brittany, France, has become the scene of a fierce and divisive battle that has pitted supporters of a plan to welcome refugees against its far-right backed opponents. Tensions came to head on November 5 when both sides held rival demonstrations in the town.
articles.title: 'Climate of fear’: Battle over refugee project divides small Brittany town

articles.author: Leela JACINTO
articles.description: Detained Egyptian activist Alaa Abdel Fattah’s decision to escalate a hunger strike in prison to a refusal to drink water has raised the stakes and shone a spotlight on human rights violations as Egypt hosts the COP27 climate summit. For his mother, the time has come for the world to act and not be hoodwinked by Egypt’s greenwashing of human rights.
articles.title: ‘I’m very worried’: Mother of jailed Egyptian activist on hunger strike wants action

articles.author: Khatya CHHOR
articles.description: Midterm Congressional elections are almost always a win for the opposition party, leaving Democrats fighting an uphill battle to hold on to their razor-thin Senate majority. With pre-election polls indicating that contests in several crucial states are still too close to call, here are five of the races to watch.
articles.title: US midterms: Five of the key Senate races to watch on election night

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Eleven former or serving French bishops have been accused of sexual violence, including the former bishop of Bordeaux who has confessed to assaulting a minor 35 years ago, a senior church body announced Monday.
articles.title: Eleven French bishops accused of sexual violence

articles.author: Valérie DEFERT
articles.description: One of the key issues on US voters' minds during the upcoming midterm elections will be gun control. Around 40,000 people die from gun violence in the country each year. After every mass shooting, the same questions are asked about whether to restrict access to weapons. In the weeks following the deadly school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, Congress managed to pass a bipartisan bill on gun control. The Uvalde shooting is now pushing Democrats to field candidates for local office, but they face a highly divided electorate in Texas. Our correspondents Pierrick Leurent and Valérie Defert report, with Wassim Cornet.
articles.title: US midterm elections: Texan voters divided over gun control

articles.author: Marc PERELMAN
articles.description: In an interview with FRANCE 24, US Deputy Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyemo discussed the sanctions imposed on Moscow in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. "The sanctions are working and that's why Russia is working so hard to evade them," he said. Adeyemo also discussed the cap on the price of Russian oil announced by the G7. He confirmed that this "will happen" on December 5 and predicted a knock-on effect among other buyers of Russian oil, such as China and India, who will likely demand lower prices as a result.
articles.title: Sanctions on Russia 'are working', US deputy treasury secretary says

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Holders Real Madrid will face English Premier League side Liverpool once again in the Champions League last 16 -- a repeat of last season's final -- while Paris St Germain will take on German champions Bayern Munich.
articles.title: Champions League last 16: Liverpool draw Real Madrid in rematch of last season's final

articles.description: Hadis Najafi, 22. Sarina Esmailzadeh, 16. Nika Shahkarami, 16. These young people have become martyrs of the anti-regime protests in Iran. Their names have become hashtags and rallying cries for the thousands taking to the streets. They are among the more than 300 people who have been killed in the massive demonstrations, according to Oslo-based NGO Iran Human Rights.
articles.title: Iran's younger generation at the heart of the protest movement

articles.author: Rawad TAHA
articles.description: Lebanon and Israel have signed a historic agreement demarcating a long-disputed maritime border after years of US-mediated negotiations, paving the way for Lebanon to exploit the energy resources off its coast. However, analysts point out that Lebanon lacks the infrastructure and governance for a rapid shift to becoming an oil-exporting nation, so the deal is unlikely to offset the nation’s economic and social crises in the short term.
articles.title: After maritime border deal with Israel, Lebanon looks to capitalise on underwater oil exploration

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Armenia and Azerbaijan on Monday traded accusations of provoking a shootout along their troubled border, just hours before the arch-foes were to hold US-mediated peace talks.
articles.title: New shooting along Azerbaijan, Armenia border hours before US-mediated talks

articles.author: Alison SARGENT
articles.description: The UN's annual climate change conference grows more urgent every year. With just over 1.1°C of warming above pre-industrial levels, the world is already seeing devastating consequences. As COP27 opens in Egypt, we discuss the stakes at this year's summit with Inger Andersen, executive director of the United Nations Environment Programme. She explains that current pledges remain largely insufficient and calls on G20 countries – responsible for more than 75 percent of carbon emissions – to ensure climate justice. Her message to all those disappointed with current climate action: Elect leaders who will be sure to make it a priority.
articles.title: Climate justice at COP27: ‘Richer countries cannot turn their backs on this’

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Facebook-parent Meta will become the latest tech firm to scale back its workforce, with plans to layoff thousands of employees this week, US media reported Sunday.
articles.title: Facebook parent company Meta planning mass layoffs, Wall Street Journal reports

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Monday that 50,000 Russian soldiers called up as part of his mobilisation drive were now serving with combat units in Ukraine, the Interfax news agency reported. Read our live blog to see how the day's events unfold. All times are Paris time (GMT+1).
articles.title: Live: Putin says 50,000 mobilised Russian soldiers serving with combat units

articles.description: Over the past two years, Republican states in the US have passed several voting rights laws and measures under the guise of fighting voter fraud. The new rules, experts warn, are opening avenues for voter intimidation and poll interference, making the midterm elections on November 8 a test of the US election system and of American democracy.

articles.title: US midterms: Biden slams Republicans while Trump urges voters to oppose Democrats

articles.title: Rising inflation top concern for G20 countries, according to survey

articles.title: Britain's Sunak will urge leaders at COP27 to deliver on climate promises

articles.title: Teenager Holger Rune wins first tennis master title in Paris against Djokovic

articles.description: Running from Uganda to Egypt, the Nile is essential to the survival of millions of people living in Africa. But a combination of climate change and human overuse is drying up the river, and worsening conditions for farmers who fear low harvests and loss of electricity.
articles.title: Crisis on the Nile: Global warming and overuse threaten Africa’s longest river

articles.title: Ukraine has capability to retake Kherson from Russia: Pentagon chief

articles.title: Commentary: Who is responsible when climate change harms the world’s poorest countries?

articles.description: Political contests in the United States Congress are seen as focused on local personalities and issues that matter less to the rest of the world. But there could be wider repercussions on American foreign policy, such as support for Ukraine or the hawkish stance on China, says Yale-NUS College’s Trisha Craig.

articles.title: Zelenskyy says he will not take part in G20 summit if Putin does

There was silence from senior officials in Moscow. The Kyiv
articles.title: Russia signals retreat in southern Ukraine but Kyiv fears trap

"The winter is coming. Putin is waiting for the 'General Winter' to come a
articles.title: World must stand with Kyiv as Putin counts on 'General Winter', EU says

articles.title: Grain shipments resume as G7 vows winter help for Ukraine

Kwek Kee Seng, who owns the Swanseas Port Services shippi
articles.title: US offers US$5 million reward for Singaporean over North Korea oil shipments

It now expects vaccine sales of US$18 billion to US$19 billion this year compared to
articles.title: Moderna cuts COVID-19 vaccine sales forecast on supply woes, shares tumble

articles.title: UN chief urges focus on ambition, trust at Egypt climate summit

articles.title: Sterling drops as BoE hikes interest rates but diverges from Fed

The BoE increased borrowing costs by 0.75 percentage points to 3 per cent,&nb

The shortages are worse than what the country experienced at the he
articles.title: Two thirds of South Sudan population risk severe hunger in 2023: UN

With more than 90 per cent of ballots counted, according to the
articles.title: Israel's Netanyahu set for return to power with far-right help

Following a regular meeting, the BoE is expected to lift borrowing costs by 0.75 percentage points to 3 per cent, accor
articles.title: Bank of England set for biggest rate hike in 33 years

The Communities feature will b
articles.title: WhatsApp launches Communities group organiser feature

The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in southern Ukraine has aga

That could be heartening for climate scientists, who say shifting diets from emission
articles.title: In meat-loving South Africa, climate concerns whet appetite for veggie burgers

articles.description: With the U.S. midterm elections expected to grow the influence of the far-right, anti-democratic movement, one expert says pro-democracy forces need to get tougher.
